ISAs will be a part of the solution, 'debt' is better than 'equity' for many. The key change needed is for schools/training institutes to be on the hook for the education outcomes I launched an Income Share Agreement (ISA) company in 2019.

Our company survived, but our use of ISAs did not.

Overall, I think the ISA experiment has failed and is not the revolution we hoped would transform training and education.

Here's what I learned

With the exception of a few, most of the coding camps are just committing the same mistakes we lament about the current education system. Or even narrowing the scope of things you learn via rote learning in a shorter timeframe.
#WorkFromHome bubble has burst. Empowering individuals to make informed choices will be the way forward for true productive gains

Gentle advice for "learn to code" grads: You still need to study computer science and software engineering text books. 

Making it easier to get started also makes it easier to hit a wall at speed. 

Don't crash bad. Study up.
Before you skip college based on Twitter advice, do ask yourself how many rigorous technical books (not youtube videos) you've developed the capacity to complete yourself.

Incidentally Trell was a company that offered ESOP buybacks worth $1.6 million this year. Crazy, that they use the money they raised to buyback but at the same time fire employees.
